text: This book crushed me in the best way possible. At first, I didn't understand what was going on. I just knew that I liked the writing style and the characters, and that I liked the sort of painful feeling that came through the story, haunting but beautifully translated into writing. This story is both dark and joyful. It made me cry and smile, sometimes even laugh. It's a beautiful story of friendship, love, and grief that doesn't spare the readers but still manages to instill in them the desire to live, and to belong. I'm forever grateful that I picked this book up.

LOVED IT! Such a good book. So much emotion, family discovery, friendships, and romance. This book covers everything. I could not put it down. "In my room I lie on my bed, sick to the stomach and I want to cry because my mind is working too much. All I know is that there is something not right. It's in my dreams, it's inside my heart, and without Hannah here, it's an all-consuming feeling of doom"(Marchetta 130). This is an example of beautiful writing Marchetta used throughout the book.
My favorite book in the whole entire world. Have read it more times than I can count and it will never get old.

I keep saying I don’t like contemporary YA but apparently I just haven’t been reading the right YA authors. This was such a unique story. Taylor is a teenager abandoned by her mother and who now lives at a boarding school. The woman who she is most attached to disappears one day and Taylor is desperate to find out where she went. In the meantime, the school is entrenched in territory wars with students from other organizations, including one led by a boy with whom Taylor has a lot of history. Entwined in this narrative are portions of a story written by the missing woman which offer hints of Taylor’s past. I thought the teenagers were written exceptionally well. Sometimes I just don’t feel like YA authors are writing recognizable teenagers. I love teenagers and teach high schoolers and the conversations and humor that Marchetta has created were so authentic. I love the relationships that were built and the realistic portrayal of their emotions. I have already put a library hold on Marchetta’s other books and look forward to picking them up!
Just perfect

A tough slog in the beginning, with talks of territory wars, and a sideline story which felt very disconnected. Eventually, the characters developed, the intrigue built and I was hooked. A real page turner for the second half. Recommend.
it was perfect
This book took a bit of time to get into but then was a real joy ride that I enjoyed a lot. More of 4 and a half for me.

Jellicoe Road is dark and tragic in a hauntingly beautiful way. It is imaginative, poetic, emotional, and masterfully written. It is young adult fiction with very mature themes (e.g. childhood trauma, drug addiction, suicide, and death). The characters are broken down to the core, and from the depths of their vulnerability and resiliency, they find themselves. The first 100 pages of this book is confusing. It feels like fragments of a dream that you can’t quite piece together. Then at about 1/3 of the way through, it suddenly clicks, things start to make sense; you feel the haze lifting, and the dream is actually a nightmare that is as devastating as it is uplifting. I love this book for its mystery, powerful themes, and multi-layered storytelling.
I may have been too young to grasp it when I read it, or perhaps I just had too high expectations for it

i don't remember a lot beyond the general plot but i do remember it was set in Australia, it helped me get some ideas about boarding school internal hierarchies (which was the point of reading it), and every time I see the title I get this song stuck in my head that goes "on the jericho road / there's room for just two / no more and no less / just Jesus and you" only my brain goes "on the jellicoe road" idk why am I like this

This book was comprised of two very different reading experiences for me. The first half was unenjoyable. I was utterly lost and had to continually scan the beginning pages to figure out what Melina was referring to. It took alot of self control not to stop reading and go onto something else. Then the second half of the book happened. Finally I understood what was going on and began to enjoy the novel. I just wish things were a bit clearer in the beginning.
I had a bit of trouble getting into this book at first but once I dived in!! Let me tell you I could not stop falling in love with the characters, especially Griggs!
holy shit I read this in one sitting on a plane,,,,holy shit

I don’t recommend this book especially if you have a hard time following along. There were too many characters and while in the end it all came together it was not worth my time especially because all the events seemed insignificant, almost like page fillers. It was also quite confusing at times, dark and stressed me out a lot. I would compare it to a mixture of Riverdale, Legacies, The Bride to Teribithia, and the Outsiders. I felt like I was reading a book forced upon me by an English teacher. Lastly I don’t feel that I took much away from this book other than anger because I could have read a way better book. And what was with ALL THE WEIRD CHARACTER NAMES???
My god I'm so glad I held out on this one. The first half was so slow, but then it all started to make sense and ended up being more profound than I thought it would be.

I have read this book about 5 times and each time I finish it in one sitting. I love the interweaving of the story of Taylor with Narni's story and how the history of the Jelicoe road is formed by the writings. This also makes re-reading the book very rewarding since you pick up nuances and small points that you didn't that first time you read it.

This story has layers and complexity and is just like a puzzle. Melina Marchetta wrote this book wonderfully—the way the book ended in full circle is brilliant and absolutely beautiful. The characters have depth and their voices are unique. I read this book once and immediately re-read it the day after, as, although the layers and complexity of this book make it captivating, it also makes it a bit difficult to piece things together and remember everything. Reading it again makes me appreciate everything this book has to offer so much more. The first section of the book is a bit difficult to swallow, even for the second time reading it, with confusing details that barely make sense, but they got better, and the confusing-ness really reflects the thought process of Taylor Markham, the main character. That being said, I don't love the plot as much as I loved the writing. Things got confusing or weird or dramatic at times, but I enjoyed this book for the puzzle it is and for its characters and the way things are set up. Overall, I spent one month reading and reflecting on and fully comprehending this book, and I'm glad I did.

I'm not usually the kind of reader who will press on even when I'm incredibly confused, but Jellicoe Road is special for some reason. I had no idea what was happening for at least the first third, and I loved it to bits anyway. And once things do become clear...well, it's a masterwork.

This book was heart wrenching. It also tried way too hard to throw plot twists at you, so it made everything vague and hard to follow so that it could surprise you. It was beautifully written and was very compelling, clearly because I couldn't put it down.

This book was a hard read. It took me about 200 pages to get into, and I barely understood what was going on plot wise until then. There's so little description of scenery and even characters, that at times it felt like I was reading a script for a film. However, I did like the characters, found the story interesting enough, and I cried at the end. I'm also cutting it some slack as I started a new job almost at the time I started reading it, and I was so exhausted for the first few weeks, that I barely had the energy to read, let alone understand a kind of complicated narrative. So that's why I'm giving it three stars instead of two.

I didn't think I would love this book this much, but I do. Can't wait to buy a physical copy and read it again I love each and every character and I already miss them 🥺Definitely a book everyone should read! In the beginning it might be really confusing but hang on that everything will make sense
This is the best book I have ever read. By far my absolute favourite.
I gave it a good try and read more than half of it. I just couldn’t get into it. I listened on audible and it just didn’t seem to go anywhere so I gave up and returned it.

I feel very left out for not enjoying this book… The first 200 pages are about these territory wars between kids that make little to no sense. This isn’t really the main plotline so I have no idea why this was such a huge part of the novel. The last two hundred pages get better in that you get some answers about Taylor’s past and family, but you figure it out on your own and then you still have another 100+ pages to get through. Like this book won the Printz award in 2009? Maybe I would have enjoyed it more if I read it back then/when I was younger.

After reading so many positive reviews, I bought this for my teenaged granddaughter and only then read it. I should have read it first. The first half of the book was so hard to follow, I would have set it aside had I not been determined to see if it lived up to the glowing reviews. The story has real potential, but the execution is rambling. The story is nearly unrelentingly dark, but a dark novel with a compelling, well-told story is worth the journey. This one left me with a bad taste and a sense of wasted reading hours. What I like about it is that the book attracts avid fans. So one day I will look forward to a conversation with my granddaughter about it. Her perspective may make me decide to re-read it, with new eyes.

Heartbreaking, beautiful written , would read more of this author’s work Taylor was insufferable for a good chunk of the book, and it’s nice that even her potiential(spoiler eventual love interest/boyfriend ?) called her out on it , but it was actually albeit just as irritating to read, but sometimes more justified than ALL CAPS Harry in the order of the phoniex book(this coming from a life long/ forever hp fan of fandom as a positive and life changing thing for millions ).
review to come...

This is one of the most incredible books written by anyone, ever. I have been reading since I was three. I own thousands of books and have read thousands more in every genre imaginable and there is nothing like this one, anywhere. I wish I could buy a copy for everyone in the world so we could all have our hearts strengthened by these characters and the love and grit and sheer stubborn life of the words on these pages. I will be rereading this book for the rest of my life.I now have the kindle and the audiobook, and huge shoutout for the narrator, Rebecca Macaulay, I’m so glad she has an Australian accent and manages to tell this story so well.
A book in which a serial killer and five arsonists are just mentioned casually is pretty hardcore.Wonderfully written, expertly woven.
broke my heart
marchetta really went for the jugular on this onealso jonah griggs please date me challenge

This book destroyed me in the best way possible. I loved the characters and the character development, as well as the overall plot. The twists with the older generation of characters (Jude, Fitz, Narnie, Webb, and Tate) had me flying through this book to see what happened next. Absolutely beautiful.
FUCK YEAH!!!!!

I did NOT expect to love this book so much. I bought it on a whim and based off one quote I had seen from it. But boy was I not disappointed, this book had me crying at the end. Such a heartfelt story with past and present views that make you ache to read more and more. Taylor and Jonah>>> and then the story of the 5 that created the territory wars was such a unique twist. I do admit that the beginning was so confusing and it does not give you a lot to work with, just put straight in the middle of Taylors life. But keep reading, it gets so much better!!!!
If you want the biggest book hangover of your life, read this.

Just kinda meh. Confusing introduction where I wasn’t sure what was real and what was a dream she had. I didn’t feel a strong connection to anyone either, unfortunately. The terf war was also confusing. A lot of it didn’t make sense set up wise until over 100 pages in. Would have enjoyed a better, clear picture of the setting and characters to like it more.
*4.5/5 stars*

It took me a little while to get into this one, but I kept going because I adore Melina Marchetta and she's an author I trust. I'm glad I stuck with it. This novella was tragic most of the way through and my heart just broke and broke and broke for poor Taylor and the characters around her. I found the mysteries compelling (although I solved them faster than some of the characters did, I think) and the characters seemed realistic and interesting throughout. It's a bit of a classic coming-of-age type of novel but I don't mind that. There's a cute romance. Overall it is lacking in diversity. But generally speaking, I enjoyed this novel. Not one of Marchetta's best but in the end I still think she's a genius author who can do no wrong.
Fast-paced read that is a little adult themed and very sad. A little unbelievable but not enough to ruin it. Overall, fun to read.

Wow, this book was all kinds of confusing! Too many plot lines going on, so I was really lost in the beginning. Things came together in the end, but I literally had to write down who was related to who, just to keep my head from spinning. Sad, depressing, heartbreaking…it was ok, but just wasn’t my cup of tea. (Also, why do such terrible things always happen at/near boarding schools?? Sending my kids to one would be a big NOPE. 😂)
Get through the first quarter of the book and the rest is quite good.
I think I would give this a 3.5 maybe a 4
this book drained my tear ducts
5/5this book was perfect from start to finish.it's literally perfect.

This book took me by surprise. First, it’s been on my TBR for ~6 years. I’m glad I finally read it but damn... that hurt. Glad it lived up to the hype from people I know!The blurb doesn’t really give away much so I felt like I went in blind. I’d sell this as a young adult coming-of-age story overall. There’s a bit of romance but I found the mystery aspect the best part along with the stories of the two generations. This is a sad and beautiful story that will stay with me for a while.Gave it 4 stars instead of 5 since I initially had issues with the writing. The first 1/3 of the book felt like a slow set-up I could do away with but it got so much better after as things started unraveling. A few things also didn’t age well in this book haha (it was first published in 2006!)

Can't recommend this book more. Just read it again for the 6/7/8th time and I still tear up every time. The way she writes broken people with emotions and wonder just kills me. One of my favourite books, from my favourite author!
This is one of my favourite books. Great characters, great story, beautifully written, it is joyful and heartbreaking yet life-affirming. Everyone should read this book.
bel you’re sick. i am not fine
bels going to hell

I can see why people love this book BUT it wasn’t for me- I didn’t click with any characters, and it seemed to drag on for a LONG time.I will say that once the twists and story lines start to make sense to the reader, it becomes a lot better to read - but would I read it again? Probably not.ALSO, it did make me cry for the last couple of pages, so there’s that.I generally just didn’t enjoy the writing style- I feel like the plot is good, and if it was written differently with the same plot and twists, I would like it a lot better.

These kids have gone through way serious shit that have been swept under the rug. One admittedly goes to a counsellor which is a good thing, but for the love of all things sacred, let the other characters have therapy too. The amount of trauma that they have endured should not be so easily solved by Love and Friendship anymore. Brownie points for shedding light on teen trauma, minus points for the cheesy execution.This thing isnt going to fly if it was published in the 2020s.

i absolutely love it when the main character is a raging cunt whos just a bitch to everyone so of course taylor my ride or die <3333 like i genuinely enjoy reading this kinda dynamic but only when it done on purpose not them just annoying af u know :) loved hers and griggs relationship 😻 although i do wish it was more of a slow burn like the tension at the beginning !!! when he pinned her to the wall 😦 but i think with the way the story went it made sense tho i would kill for a similar story but instead of all the mummy drama it just about the whole territory war like listen to this leaders of rival teams who once ran away together 3 years before and the girl thinks he betrayed her but he never did, she saved his life without even knowing and he called and wrote to her for a whole year and they know all the bad parts of each other so the tension is high because they know how to get to each other😝😝like they had it all!! i really liked how the book was written but i was hella confused at the start like u kinda just get thrown in and r expected to know what going on like i deadass thought they were in a real war for sec and then this side-story just pops up and ur like who the fuck r these randos hello?? but once u get it and it all starts adding up you appreciate it so much more. one thing that really pissed me off tho was the pacing of the book and how it would just cut to something else like like there was this part where griggs was like that day at the train station when i met u i lied i wasn’t going to visit my mum i went there kill myself and then chapter ended and then next chapter was back to the war negotiating like wait a minute go back GO BACK!! i would like to know what happened next u can’t just leave it at that 😕 again would kill for a book with this kinda of group dynamic because i love them but it was so sudden like hey we besties now after being you know at war with one another i think the whole mum and hannah business overshadowed this whole part of the story so it felt rushed so a similar book focused on the development of the group and their friendship is a need 😄🤲
I will be thinking about this for the next 3 days or so.

I really enjoyed this book, though I did find it harder to get myself into than Looking for Alibrandi or Saving Francesca, however from the halfway point I was unable to put it down. Another thoroughly enjoyable book from Melina Marchetta.
Great.
If I would have read this in high school or early college, it would have absolutely blown me away. Just beautiful.
I’m a sobby mess right now. I wish I’d read this sooner!

This was everything I hoped it would be! I was looking for something heartbreaking and full of love and friendship and also uplifting and this was exactly what I needed. There's nothing like a story about teenagers (and also some people in their thirties like me) to make you feel all the feels. Precious.
was very confused at the beginning of this book but ended up crying my guts out.

I’m going to know them until the day I die.”this book is my religion and has been since i was 13.----------rereading my absolute favourite classics (i'm on my fitzgerald and austen binge reread because they were the only ones who made me feel anything when i was young) and books that destroyed 14 year old me seems to be the theme of july and i am not giving up!!i don't understand folks who love summer more than anything. the only thing i feel these months is crippling nostalgia and sadness at 4pm.
i've read it twice in one week, i think that sums it up

I’ve read this book first in 2010, and have since reread it many times whenever I’m looking for comfort. It always manages to make me cry. Exquisite young adult fiction. My only gripe is that the narrative of the five kids (Hannah’s manuscript) is difficult to piece together and not as easy to connect with as Taylor’s voice. Still, one of my favourite reads.

I haven’t read a book this quickly in a while. Fantastic book with a chaotic, yet interesting plot. I cried all the way through. I’m only giving it two stars rather than five, because of the constant racist remarks throughout the book. They made me extremely uncomfortable, and quite frankly they were just unnecessary. This book was written in the early 2000’s…so we definitely can’t blame it on the time and place in history. Perhaps the author is a racist?

I had no idea what was happening for the first 150 pages so I'm not sure if I enjoyed it.But I'm dedicated to Melina Marchetta so I ended up crying in the last few chapters. Not sure if it's better than Saving Francesca/The Piper's Son/Dalhousie.Probably need a few days to process.

I appreciate the opportunity to explore older Australian YA, which has a very different tone and focus than what we anticipate in YA lit today. This novel, however, did not work for present-me - though I'll admit it probably would have been my jam if I had read it when it came out in 2006. The timeline/narrative shifts were confusing and even when these stories converged, I found my interest waning. I always appreciate the discussion that comes with book club but not my favorite pick.

When the secrets slowly gets unravelled and the intricate puzzle pieces start to fall together, you realise in the heart of it all, this is a love story with so many layers and so many surprises- exactly the kind of YA contemporary I have been looking forever to be so fond of, the kind with a certain air of mystery, tragedy and emotion without being so overly dramatic.

Interesting story, I honestly was confused as a book reader for part of it. Prob because I feel asleep while listening to audiobook and got lost on friend groups. Character development created an interesting story.
my favourite book ever. can read and reread endlessly. the characters and the unravelling of the storyline is effortless and beautiful.

Yes, I was severely confused for half of the book and then I started figuring things out and it was kind of worth the insanity I had to go through. I do love when there are switching storylines and the added suspense that came with it in this novel, especially as things began to make more sense. I felt like the mysteries were easy for me to figure out and that made me feel smart and proud of myself. However, it also made me frustrated at the main character for not piecing it together yet. I definitely became more interested in Taylor’s story but I also needed to know how the other storyline would end. I really liked the sense of deja vu I kept feeling within this book and all the connections that I wasn’t sure about. Even with all the links I made, I feel like I missed so many more and would need to read this multiple more times to really understand what all the author is doing with the different narrative devices she uses. There is a lot of trauma in this book and I’m still confused as to how much fictionalized trauma is a ridiculous amount for me, in context.
will i ever recover from this book? no

3.5 stars. I thought the characters were interesting, and the coming-of-age / mystery / romance / family drama mashup worked for me, but I just found it hard to get into this book. I’d say by the second half / last third I was fully engrossed but until then it was slow going.

I can’t really describe it but this book just has this “Australia-atmosphere“ to it. Ever since I lived in Australia for a while I’ve had this longing for a childhood living there and reading this book now made me a little sad because of that.The beginning was a little confusing to me and I didn’t really get what was going on for the first three or four chapters.Overall it was a good read but I didn’t enjoy it as much as I enjoyed “Looking for Alibrandi“.
A dreamlike, amazing, adventurous ya I've read in a while.
need this in every edition tenks
It was believable, kept me interested, and left me wanting more.

The first 30-50% is just hard to follow until more information is revealed. It’s got a lot of melodrama and definitely feels targeted towards teens, so I rolled my eyes a lot as an adult. I don’t know, maybe the author hit the sweet spot for brain development, but I found it a little insipid.

To be honest, I think I read this book to quickly. I felt like I was always missing something while reading this text, and I'm not sure I necessarily want to re-read it to find out what I missed because it seemed just sad.
I have no idea what is it about this book, but this sticks with me.
3.5 stars
i accidentally deleted all my reread dates & my old reviews :'( but hey i adore this book so much - the characters, the story, the writing - they all mean a whole big lot to me

My Australian stop in the #readtheworld challenge and a beautiful multigenerational love story and bildungsroman.I love the atmosphere, the kids and the development of the story and the mystery and phrases like these: It’s funny how you can forget everything except people loving you. Maybe that’s why humans find it so hard getting over love affairs. It’s not the pain they’re getting over, it’s the love.I laughed and cried and I recommend it fully more for the story than for the setting.

I read the entire book mostly in one sitting except for the last few pages which is a real testament to the quality of the writing and the interest of the plot. I will say that things that you’re supposed to wonder were definitely predictable but I don’t see this as a mystery novel so that doesn’t really matter. Read this if you’re a hopeless romantic and you want to get emotional

There are some books that stay with you for awhile, and this is definitely one of them. This sat on my shelf for years and this year I was finally ready to read it as it was recommended by an editor to learn about good writing and characterisation.It's so wonderfully constructed-- it's like with each chapter, you carefully peel back the layers of the story and something beautiful is revealed underneath. I live for books where you turn the final page and you're like "Wow. That was something." Some readers might begin this story and feel a little confused, but if you persist through that confusion, eventually everything becomes clear and it's VERY worth it.As soon as I was finished, I wanted to read it again! Highly recommend.
One of my favorite YA stories, ever. Have reread this once or twice before, but each time I can feel the characters' emotions so strongly it hurts my heart. Highly highly recommend!

This is a strong character driven YA novel. As many reviewers have mentioned, the beginning is confusing. The story jumps around introducing a developing characters without a clear link between them. If you don’t enjoy character development then the first third of this book will be a slog. However that’s my fiction happy-place, so this held my interest. For those who recognize the real places in the book, the references are evocative. The plot felt over embellished but stayed just shy of farcical. A worthwhile YA read for sure.
I love this book with all my heart and have read it several times.

Marchetta is the master of writing a single line that will cut you in half without warning. She is like a prose ninja. Four stars because the genre isn't my cup of tea, but that is a me problem. The book is fantastic.

Believe me, I tried to like this book, but the lackluster and predictable story made it so difficult. I actually only finished this because I already DNFed two books. It had its good moments, I particularly loved the narrative about the five kids and would've liked it better if the book was actually about them instead lol (it was one of the very few things that pushed me to keep reading this book). I appreciate the good writing and the development of the characters (especially the female MC whose name I already forgot and don't even wanna bother to look up). Also, why do a lot of people like Jonah Griggs so much? Did I miss something?
This book started out so confusing and stupid I decided to not put myself thru it. Didn’t realize it was young adult but thought maybe I’d enjoy it anyway. Nope.
Even though I really enjoyed this book, I’m docking a star because of all the unnecessary secret keeping that goes on throughout. Other than that, just an absolutely lovely book.

I am in ruins! I am a mess! I finished this book last night and I WEPT through the last few chapters! My heart has been ripped out of my chest. My God, this book! This book is BREATHTAKING! This book is a triumph! It is that truly rare gem that you know will forever redefine excellence in your mind, and every other “great” book will now be compared to, and you already know will likely pale in comparison to. This book is the BEST YA novel I have ever read. This book may be one of the best books I have EVER read in my LIFE!Honestly, I don’t have the words to describe the astonishing beauty that is this story and this prose. What a privilege it was to have this reading experience! What a privilege it was to know these characters! What a privilege it was to be captivated by this gorgeous prose! A friend of mine who’s an avid reader had been recommending this book to me for years! I wish I had listened to her much earlier! This book should have been my absolute priority! When I finally started reading it, I was very confused! I spent the first 25% of the book not knowing what is going on. In fact, I read the first 25% twice, in hopes of finding some important info I had missed the first time. Then I got very nervous that I’m not going to like the book because it doesn’t make sense and I’m going to disappoint my friend by going back and saying I have no idea what she liked about this book! O, Ye of Little Faith! I needn’t have worried one bit! Every single sentence here has a purpose. Every single piece of the puzzle will masterfully fall into place. It all comes together BEAUTIFULLY! I don’t really want to talk about the plot. In my opinion, it’s best to go into this book knowing as little as possible about it. And if you really need to know what the story is about, it’s been discussed in great detail by so many other reviewers. I’d rather talk about how it made me FEEL all the feelings. Suffice to say that the book explores some heavy themes, but at its heart, it is a coming of age story; a story about finding who you are and where you belong, and where you long to be. it’s a story about devastating heartbreak, loneliness, immense loss, but also resilience, the absolute healing power of friendships, the beauty of first love, and the places and people who make us feel like we are home.This book has a complex plot, one that is structured intricately. There are dual narratives and a large cast of characters. You could say there’s a lot going on, and the book is under 300 pages! But what you have to understand is that this is not your average run of the mill YA. You’re in the hands of a true genius! This is a rich and complicated tale. And it’s very sophisticated, both in the themes it explores, and in the art of storytelling. The author seamlessly moves between the dual narratives, and slowly, slowly, unravels the mystery elements and unspools the thread that will connect all the pieces.By the end, you’ll sit there, absolutely stunned. Not just by how the dual narratives come together perfectly and harmoniously, but by the small details, the subtle connections that truly take your breath away. You’ll come to find that nothing was wasted here. That every little comment, every tidbit of info, and every thought was there for a reason, and they all create such a tsunami of emotions within you! The prose is truly hauntingly beautiful. Melina Marchetta is an astonishing wordsmith! Few can do what she has done here! Very few!It is extraordinary how the author manages such a large cast of characters so masterfully. Every character is rich and three-dimensional, and I couldn’t help but to care about each and every one of them. God, I don’t remember having read many books where I fell so deeply in love with so many of the characters, even the minor ones. And the punchy dialogues! They were so real. I giggled reading some of them. But then again, I also cried many times, reading Taylor’s narration of her story. What an emotional rollercoaster this was!This book did something to me. It sliced through my heart, cut a piece of it, and stole it forever! This is a book I will never forget! One I suspect I will come back to again in the future. This book deserves to be read by all, and not just young adults. Not the likes of Twilight, which for some incomprehensible reason steals the spotlight. This is the caliber YA literature should be.I kneel before you  Melina Marchetta. You’ve bewitched me. You’ve somehow bottled up magic and served it up in this 300-page package. Thank you for this book! We are not worthy!5 shiny starts, but only because the GoodReads scale cannot do this book justice! P.S: I know this book was written before the age of hashtags on social media, but can we make this hashtag a thing? #JonahGriggsForever

Wow. I flew through this book so quickly that I feel like I need to go back and savour it all again. While the beginning of OTJCR is definitely confusing and seems (almost) dystopian, PERSEVERE! After a hundred or so pages it all becomes clear, and you begin to go deeper with the characters & connect with them. It's one of the best YA novels I think I've ever read; it's real and gritty, with flawed characters that don't make all the right choices, but you at least understand why they do what they do.I'm a sucker for good character development, and I do feel like Taylor - and some of the supporting characters to a lesser extent (Jude! Jonah!)- go through quite a bit of change; I love watching as characters learn to open up and let people in. I really liked the 2 timelines, and trying to put together the pieces of the puzzle and figure it out. The more I think about it, the more parallels I can see between the 2 friend groups and their stories. (I love way the 2nd group is kind of a redemption of the 1st, and they come out even stronger). The friendships that are formed are my favourite part, I loved Chaz, Raffy, Jonah!!, and Taylor. Around 60% I did figure out the biggest "reveal", but I was still eager to see how the characters would find out. It's a beautifully written book about broken, hurting people and the friendships that save them. (I'm a sucker for cool friend groups, they made me think of the Marauders in a way).

First, I listened to the Audible version. I don't recommend it. From reading other reviews, I'm not alone in this thinking. This story is SUPER confusing and requires your undivided attention. I had to start it over after reading reviews that told me there were TWO stories being told at the same time. I totally didn't get that in the audiobook.I think I like the premise, but there are things about it that I just thought were pointless-like the territory wars. I still don't understand how that had any bearing on the actual story. It seemed kind of pointless and added to the confusion. The first half of the book is incredibly confusing. When the big reveals comes out half way through, your head starts to get unmuffled, but why do you have to go through half a book of confusion to get there?Not my favorite book.

This beautiful book is an ode to friendship and longing for a place to call home. Written in a semi-dark atmosphere, the author combines the past, the present and the future, revealing teenagers that only want to belong, to live for one another. However, you don’t feel the need to give up reading on it, the story grabs you in a way that you can’t let go. In the end, you are only left with that human emotion through which life goes on. Beautiful book, definitely worth reading!

And life goes on, which seems kind of strange and cruel when you're watching someone dieThere’s this heavy feeling in my chest. Melina Marchetta did it again, she wrenched my heart. This book was really… something. It started off very confusing, not going to lie, therefore hard to stick to it. Kids talking about House leaders and territory wars and what faction owns what and Taylor’s very difficult personality and my attention span was not having it. It was also hard to differentiate what was a POV, what was a flashback and a dream, it took me until chapter 9, where our protagonist mentions one of the original 5’s name as part of a story she is reading that I realized what was what from whom. And then, Taylor grew on me just like her house girls grew on her and I understood her and where she was coming from and I just could not stop reading. I just needed to know what happened to these 5 kids and I just needed Taylor to get her answers and I needed to know how all their lives were connected. Marchetta has a talent for that, knotting people’s lives in her stories in such a beautiful way. I have so much love for Taylor and Jonah and Raffaela and Chaz and Ben and Jessa even Anson Choi and the Mullet Brothers. It was beautiful to see their friendship bloom. I had the strong need to protect every single one of these characters throughout the whole book.I am in love with the way Marchetta writes emotions, and how strongly you can feel her characters feel them. She also has a talent for presenting you a character who you might not see in a good light at the beginning and instead of giving them this miraculous redemption arc, she explains their reasons and you, without noticing, accept this character, root for them. Fucked up characters doing their best to survive. My kind of book.
i hope one day i find a place where i can belong or long to be like jellicoe road

4/5 - I was blown away by the build-up of the storyline and the ending of this book. It was intense and gripped me so much that I almost couldn't believe it was YA fiction. It's a book centred on teenaged characters, but it feels very mature, and a lot of the subject matter is heavy and dark - I don't think I could imagine myself reading this as a teenager. I thought the way the author connected the characters and tied up all the storylines was very elegant. Half the story is written from the main character, Taylor Markham's perspective, while the other half is written in italics. At first it was really difficult to keep the two storylines and numerous characters separate, but at the end, it becomes very clear and every character is significant and has a clear connection to each storyline. I took 1 star away because I thought the "territory war" between the Townies and the Cadets seemed juvenile and out of place. I felt that it wasn't as realistic as it could have been, because the characters seemed so mature, and at the same time they were participating in some odd war game. I wish the plot didn't centre so much on the territory war since it was pretty insignificant near the end. Anyway - if you are a fan of YA fiction and are looking for something that is well-written and mature, I would recommend this one. (CW: (view spoiler)[ drug addiction, suicide, mentions of pedophilia  (hide spoiler)])

Taylor Markham, a teen going to school at the Jellicoe School is chosen to lead the new section of a game between the neighboring groups containing the townies, and the cadets. As she tries to learn and understand her new role as a leader and fight off those intending to vote her out, her past begins to catch up with her. She knows that her friend Hannah knows more about her past than she has let on, but when Hannah goes missing Taylor is left wondering just how much she knows. The leader of the cadets is Jonah, another reminder of her past that she is forced to reconcile. Trying to juggle a pretend war, school, her past, and the sudden vanishment of Hannah leaves Taylor struggling to understand herself and what's important. I found myself relating to Taylor a lot more than I thought I would. Her struggle with her mental health because of her past is relatable and heartwarming. Hannah's story is also being told during the novel, and while I enjoyed it sometimes it took me out of the story that I typically found myself right in the middle of. I was rooting for the main characters the entire time and appreciated how unique tone of voice the author had. ◦ Sexual Abuse◦ Child Neglect◦ Drug Abuse◦ Themes of Suicide

3.5/5I'm very torn about this book. Is it three? four? five stars?It was very confusing in how it was put together, like someone ripped out a hand full of random pages from different sections of a long story, and stapled them together in a mash-mash order.It was also frustrating how the "revelations" the book built up to were so obvious from the very beginning. Classic childhood YA fave. Read it again for nostalgic reasons and to remember my writing roots - I’m a sucker for the type of gorgeous, lyrical, poetic prose that bursts out of this book. Some of the dialogue felt forced and unnatural, especially in how the boys interact with each other and it was somewhat off putting, if I were being hypercritical I’d say it perpetuates the toxic trope of men’s aggression and emotional repression. However, to place this within context, it matches the background of these characters. Grippingly unshakable whimsical book.

How does one even begin to review Jellicoe Road?Anything I type will seem not enough. If I searched for the finest combination of words and managed to come up with a pragmatic sentence like “this book was a primal example of top-notch storytelling”, it would be like diminishing the lengths of its emotional reach just to make it fit in a closed space of category, turn it into something you can shelve and put away, and it deserves more than that. Marchetta’s story was an orchestra of paradoxes that exploded and sunk into itself at the same time — it talked about love and hate, comfort and grief, harvesting and destruction, life and death. It talked about friendships and war and how sometimes it can only take one second for your entire world to fall apart, burn into dust. And I can’t even begin to express how reading it felt so heavy, like the weight of gravity was suddenly pressing down on me, and the cold melancholy it oozed out of every chapter frosted my fingertips and made me feel numb. I don’t know if my next sentence will make sense, but this was the type of story that makes you feel like you’ve drunk too much and that the world is moving too fast for your hungover brain to keep up with everything — which is good. Art means a whole lot more when it is capable of inciting emotions of that caliber in someone.Don’t ask me to explain the logistics of this book. It was confusing and a little nauseating at first, seeing the feud between the Cadets, the school and the Townies present itself with scattered pieces and chaotic figures. But trust me when I say that the unfolding of the thread that binds these three forces is an experience unlike anything you’ve read before. Through the painfully nostalgic perspective of Taylor, the story behind the accident that happened in Jellicoe Road and of the people who lost a family but gained another because of it appears like colorful dust in the air and reading about it is like trying to grab everything at once. But your hands get stained and there’s still so much to see and you want to consume this book all at once even though it’s so sad and inflammable that it hurts. I loved it so much but... Damn I need a walk-in-the-park of a read after it, an Emily in Paris but in book form, basically. It’s so funny because I remember putting it on my TBR months ago because I thought it’d be a YA-contemporary like a John Green book or something.... LOL
I almost marked it down to four stars because it was so sad, but it is truly a great book. Very life affirming. reminded me better than any book I've read recently what it feels like to be seventeen.

I saw that this book has amazing reviews, people cried and some reread it every chance they get, all I can say is I've never been so happy to finish a book and I didn't even care what happened at the end because Taylor was so unlikeable, Jonah had the worst first impression although he did grow on me and the flash backs seemed like they were all upside down. I didn't get the impression that the flashback characters were fleshed out properly, their characters were flat and forgettable. Jellicoe Road.What. A. Book.What am I even going to say that hasn’t been said yet? I started this book literally 2 days ago and I’ve finished it. Yep. I read 400 pages in two days. Which probably won’t be something super rare on this community but I swear it is for me; not the fact that I read it fast but the fact that I literally couldn’t stop thinking about this book when I wasn’t reading. I wanted to know more. I HAD to know more and get to the bottom of these two different stories that collide together at the end.Before doing this too long, I just wanted to say that this is my new favorite standalone. Since the first page, I’ve felt the warmth and aura of the Jellicoe Road. It’s so weird because it has never happened to me before, and it was like I was there (even if it sounds so cliché), alongside Taylor, on the Prayer Tree. I could feel what Melina wanted us to feel with this book (I promise it makes sense once you read it, it’s so difficult to express with words) and the only word that comes to my mind to describe this book is: magical.I don’t want to keep going because I’m going to burst out crying again and I think I’ve cried enough. Please read this book.Thank you for reading!

I felt a lot of feelings while reading this, but one of the primary ones was exasperation. Jellicoe Road is insanely sentimental, and if you don't have a stomach for that kind of thing, this is a tough hang. It is the most YA book of all time, and I mean that in a lot of the good ways and all of the annoying ways that implies. It's not an exaggeration to say the main character has an emotional breakdown every five pages. The number of tears shed in this book could power a water park or keep a family alive in the desert. I'm all for tears, but when every moment is given equal hurricane-esque emotional weight, it's hard to take them as seriously. (Then again, that's basically what it's like to be in high school, so it's not like it's inaccurate.)The ending is really strong, and I think the afterglow skews the ratings a bit, because the rest of the book is less so. Then again, I am not 14 years old, and this book isn't for me :) So I should probably stop talking. If nothing else, this book is genuine and deeply felt.
This book gives me orange vibes but a little bit sadder 🙃

The premise of the three adolescent groups struggling to survive despite an underlying darkness of abandonment and tragedy reminded me of 'Lord of the Flies'. Marchetta is a fine writer with introspective characterisation, but at times it was difficult to follow why the characters from the three groups were so obsessed with their territorial rights and rules. Then a scene is described very effectively and Marchetta's writing skill is evident. Her experience teaching in a boarding school is also evident. But the heirarchies seemed pointless. Maybe that is the point?
Amazing! It captured to wonder of childhood and the fears of growing. It made me love all the characters and sad when someone died. Amazing.

This is such a lovely and heartbreaking story of love, loss, family and friendship. It’s both heart-wrenching and uplifting and so captivating. It has one of the strongest and most beautiful friendships I’ve ever read about.At age eleven, Taylor Markham was abandoned by her mother. At fourteen, she ran away from boarding school, only to be tracked down and brought back by a mysterious stranger. Now seventeen, Taylor’s the reluctant leader of her school’s underground community, but her closest friend and mentor is Hannah, a woman who lives on the edge of the school grounds. When Hannah disappears Taylor’s search for her unveils a truth that might not just settle her past, but also change her future.The story is told in two different timelines, the past via a manuscript that Taylor finds, and the present. It’s so well-written and planned in every little detail and so suspenseful in how it slowly reveals the connections between events in the past and present times. It’s a beautiful story about friendship, but it also deals with a lot of heavy topics such as violence, death, grief, loneliness and desire to belong, suicide and self-harm.This book is so emotional and happy and sad at the same time. I had smiles and tears all over my face while reading it. It’s a book that made me suffer and that broke my heart, but it also made me so happy and I just loved every little thing about it! I cannot even try to explain how special and wonderful this book is, more than to say that I recommend it with all my heart!
One of my absolute favourite books of all time. Absolutely incredible book. Still love it to this day.

Predictable reveals at my age, but honestly, for teens, this book is gonna pack a punch! Great atmosphere, great build-up to the final reveal, great characters, great angst and a great ending. What more can you ask from a ya?

One of the rare books that manages to capture kindness and happiness without making it sappy. A very sweet book. You really care about the characters.The adult characters are not as well done as the adolescents.

It’s been a really long time since I’ve loved a book as much as I loved this one. The writing is lyrical and the story moving, a whole universe built in just a few words. For such a sad story the writing is so hopeful, and I loved watching as each character was developed and spun into a better version of themselves. Overall, this is a book I couldn’t wait to reread as soon as I finished, and couldn’t stop thinking about when I was done. It’s truly masterful.

The day before I started reading On the Jellicoe Road, I was wondering when in the world I would come across a worthy 5-star read. A day and a half later, after I turned the last page of this book, I wondered how in the world I hadn't picked it up before.If you like reads where a past story mixes with the present, this one's for you. I really appreciated the flow of the book. It was easy-paced and suspenseful enough. I didn't really like the final mystery-reveal-slash-plot-twist, but it made the story all the more unique.I've got a secret love for the kind of conflict like the "territory war" in On the Jellicoe Road. No weapons, just teens trying to outsmart each other following the idea of a war but without casualties. In this aspect, this book has got a lot of 
The War of the Buttons
 in it.IMO, the character growth throughout the story is worth the read. The dynamics. The growing friendships. The book starts cold and progresses towards warm. I can't say more (let's avoid spoilers, shall we) but there is a beautiful underlying message of how, most of the times, conflicts are unnecessary and founded on flimsy reasons. People set apart by differences can actually learn to like each other.

A wonderful story of how something which happened so, so long ago influenced the lives of young people - unbeknown you them. Loved the parallel story which provided a clever non-intrusive backstory to the Jellicoe Road community - townies, cadet and Jellicoe school.

Video review (as part of my November Wrap Up): https://youtu.be/4KfQycvLEHcI buddy read this with a lot of other Filipino bookworms and I'm thankful to have been able to join it because this is a book that's great for discussions.This book has an interesting and definitely different kind of arrangement from what I'm used to. It's got a very interesting first line which holds a lot of promise but the following chapters are very slow and can be confusing. The author also assumes that the readers are familiar with their local school system so it contributed to my confusion too. Now the biggest problem with this book is that it took around 150-200 pages until things really make any sense and a lot of people will understandably DNF this before getting to the turning point where the book lands an impact.
“My father took one hundred and thirty-two minutes to die.I counted.
Whether the final pivotal chapters are worth all the build up pages is really dependent on if you're reading this with others or solo. This is definitely a good book for discussion but it's also the kind of book that's very polarizing. I think this line basically sums up what kind of experience this book will take you on:
"What’s the difference between a trip and a journey?"“When we get there, you’ll understand."
A Slowly burned novel. All worth it in the end. 😭😭😭

I'm so glad I continued reading it despite almost dnfing it at chapter 3. This is a beautiful book I would never forget. Writhed in pain as I read this, and found my pieces back. Truly remarkable, HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!https://writtenbyal.wordpress.com/202...

The first few chapters were quite confusing, having to piece together what’s going on and trying to keep up with the events as well as the characters. It didn’t make much sense until after Ch 16 for me, because it felt like I just had so many questions about the setting and these kids and how the heck they’re living. After getting through the first few chapters though, I was captivated. The writing style is engrossing and the more you read it, the more you don’t want to put it down. The book got pretty heavy, which I didn’t expect! I loved how all the characters were intertwined and how the pieces slowly unraveled. It felt so messy but it was somehow woven together so well that everything just made sense in the end. This felt like a 3-star read in the beginning but after finishing it, this book deserves a 5. There were some parts that felt awkward but I loved it in its entirety. Definitely something that stays with you for a while after you finish reading it.
A very odd concept for a book, but once again the characters were all lovable, and the seamless switch between the past and the present was done flawlessly.

I loved this book. It has been on my shelves forever.The beginning started a little slow, like I was missing a 1st book or a couple early chapters. The flashbacks were also a bit confusing and to be honest even towards the end, I was confused by who some of the names were. But I did end up loving this one in the end....oh and don't we all want a little Jonah Griggs in our life?!
i don't think words can explain in words what i feel for these characters and their relationships so i am not even gonna try sorry just know that i love these characters with all my heart
This is the best book I have ever read. By far my absolute favourite.
One of the best books that I have read in school! I love the mystery and that you have to think for your self. You don’t get the answers right away. I also love all the twists in the book.
i can forgive how hard this book was to get into because in the end i loved it so much i was sobbing. found family excellence id say

If I hadn’t just read Chine, I would easily name this the best book I’ve read in grad school. At least I can name it the best contemporary YA. It will be a long time before Taylor Markham and her friends leave me ❤️
Still very firmly my favourite YA fiction. Strongly relatable, poignant and respectful of the adolescent condition. Love.

What a wild ride! This is the coming of age story of Taylor Markham, an Australian teen who was abandoned at 11. Now at boarding school, she is piecing together the pages of her past (view spoiler)[(literally, as the young woman who serves as a kind of mentor to her has been writing a manuscript/journal/memoir) (hide spoiler)]. With mystery, romance, and teen drama, this would be a good recommendation for fans of popular books from the same era (i.e. Twilight, Looking for Alaska, Just Listen, Crank, or Thirteen Reasons Why).

I think the beauty of this book lies in how harsh reality can be. It doesn’t use exaggerated language to describe tragic events. But it describes it in simple language like it is a fact of life until it roots in you deeply. That this is, indeed, life. A culmination of ugly and beautiful things that most often we don’t get to choose. We get dealt a lot and it depends on how we play the cards. The realization crept up on me slowly, until the story settled within my skin. I couldn’t read a book for a few days after because it was hard to get this story out of my mind. And that in itself is the mark of a five-star read.I love how effortlessly Marchetta weaves the tale of Fitz, Tate, Web, Narnie and Jude that took place so long in the past alongside Taylor’s own story and interspersing it with the tiny amusements of the Territory war that allowed friendships to grow between Taylor and the contemporaries from the other school. There are enough light moments to balance the dark ones out so that the book doesn’t become a total grief fest.Read the full review here - https://thezoyaproject.com/2017/12/21...

This book was certainly not bad and by the end I actually really liked where it ended up and had developed a fondness for pretty much all the characters by the time we got there. But the journey it took to get there was just so needlessly convoluted. I just felt the construction of this story didn't work for me. It's like it was doing everything possible to confuse me by constantly flitting between present and dreams and Hannah's story, but I don't feel like it actually added anything to the overall story by doing that. Like I still guessed all the revelations and it didn't make it more impactful by confusing me the entire time, I feel like if it was told in a less random time-jump way I could've felt these moments a lot more. There's these great emotional beats at the end that honestly didn't hit me the way I knew they should have because it took so long to get to it. Also the beginning plot of their 'house wars' or whatever was as dumb as it sounded and legit led nowhere. It felt like such ridiculous forced conflict and wasn't even well explained enough for me to care. It took itself far too seriously and I found myself eye-rolling for a lot of it and waiting for the real meat of the story to happen. I also found the main relationship and Taylor herself super grating. All of their decisions are beyond frustrating and I know they're teenagers and I know they need to grow in their arc, but I didn't really find myself routing for them for most of the book. By the end I enjoyed them enough separately that I was like, 'ok sure, fine' but again didn't hit me the way I felt it should've. Overall this book was just super weird. It's certainly different and I'm all for fresh ideas, but it just didn't do it for me at all. Not my fav, but I can see why others may have enjoyed it more.

This was my favorite book when I was 14. I ran to my library to get a copy after seeing a quote on Instagram. I had no idea that seeing that quote would lead me to my favorite book of all time! But since it was my favorite when I was just starting high school, I was scared that if I re-read it now that I’m older, it wouldn’t be my favorite anymore. I didn’t want the idealized version that I had in my head to leave, so I put off my re-read for years.Until I slipped into a reading slump and couldn’t stop thinking about it and found a beautiful new copy at a bookstore I only stumbled across and said “hey, this is fate.” And here I am at 2am clutching this masterpiece of a novel as close to my chest as possible wishing I could literally bury it physically into my heart because it was somehow so much better than the version I had in my head. I am cursing at myself for waiting so long to pick it up again and I am crying because I have too many feelings about this book.This will put you through it, okay? It will send you through such a spiral of emotions that in the end I promise you will be clutching it to your body just as I am right now and I promise that it will NEVER leave you. This is the only book I have ever read that I can just never stop thinking about.The characters are everything, the plot is everything, this book is EVERYTHING.It could be a little confusing in the beginning, but that’s only because you are trying to piece together Taylor’s life along with her. You feel every bit of emotion and confusion Taylor feels, and I think that is just the best kind of confusion.If I haven’t already convinced you, let me leave you with this: whenever I see this book in a store, I have a physical reaction. When I see it new, I literally almost cry and thank whatever god or force there is out there that the store even carries it and I clutch it and shake as I bring it up to the counter to buy it in a heartbeat. When I see it in a thrift store I have to just stand there in shock because I can’t imagine why anyone would get rid of it! And then of course I buy it even though I already have multiple copies because it is the book that makes me feel like it isn’t just a bundle of paper. I see a copy and I see something so beautiful, something that is almost alive, and I can’t bear to leave it behind.Read. This. Book.

One of the reviews for this book wrote "my throat has sealed up with emotion" and that is the most accurate description for what I am feeling right now. I am left sobbing and feeling raw and emotional. To me this is a book about trauma, healing, and loss, and I highly recommend it.

I love how Jude and Hannah are still in contact. I love how Taylor doesn't give up on her family. I love how her friends never leave her side. I love how strong the relationship between the original five were. I love how Raffaela and Chaz and Ben and Jessa and Chloe P. are there. I love that Jonah Griggs exists for Taylor. I love how deeply in love Tate was with Webb that it ruined her life. I love how it ruined Fitz's life too. I've read this book twice now. It still holds a special place in my heart. The author's writing style is just beautiful that it makes up for some of "over-used" tropes in this book. Yep, reading it for the second time in my quarter life definitely changes the way I love it now. There are some things that I used to love when I was younger that I do not now. However, those things are minor and they didn't change my mind and feeling toward this book. I still love it just the same. I didn't sob as hard as the first time I read this, now that I know what happens, but I still sob nontheless, just not as hard. This book is beautiful, inside and out.

This book was a little hard for me to get into at first because of all of the characters, but once I figured out who the characters were and what was going on, well, I LOVED it. It is a beautiful story and although it is very sad in parts, it is also heartwarming as well. This is a book I could read and re-read (I generally don’t re-read books because there are too many new books and too little time). But this one really touched me. Highly recommend.
It took me a minute to figure out what was happening in this story. It flips back and forth in time. There were some f words, otherwise I might have given it 5 stars

It took me days to finish this book. Why? Normally, a 290-page book takes me 3-5 hours to finish, but this book? Let's just say it needs a lot of time to digest. Maybe I should've waited 'til I'm ready for this roller coaster ride. For those of you who loves a great drama unfolding right before you, then this is your book! Not giving out any details of the plot as it would be best to enter this hole blinded.

i mean, it was fine, i guess, there's some good lines, some complex relationships - i like the characters. i've been reading a lot of reviews in hopes of better understanding why people love this book so much, and all i've concluded is that i will never understand. a lot of the reasons people have for not enjoying this book are very dumb or downright factually incorrect. all of the five star reviews just gush about the story without mentioning WHAT or WHY they liked it.

This book was confusing and boring. None of the characters seemed right. The adults acted like children and the children acted like adults. The “twists” were predictable from the first few chapters and I didn’t enjoy the writing.

Looking for Alaska meets Picnic at Hanging Rock. An Australian school story that builds slowly and earns its character development, trusting the reader to get by without exposition. Australian accent warning on the audiobook (for those not cultured enough to appreciate it!).

I absolutely LOVED this book. I had no idea what I was getting myself into when I started it, but I found myself unable to put it down once I really got started. It is a bit heavy, and that makes me a little hesitant to suggest it to many people, but for those that can handle the drama, it's worth the read.I would love to see how a group of teenagers would react to the story. I'm in college, and I don't really relate to the issues and mindset that the characters are in. It would be interesting to see how the group would perceive different aspects of the story and in particular the major miscommunication about the turf war (if you've read it, you know what I'm talking about).WarningsDrugs: mentions of serious addiction and being highSex: pretty mild, a couple moments but not graphic at all, a few veiled jokesRock and roll: teenagers engaging in a turf war (meaning some verbal fights and related teenager behavior)Language: not too much, a handful of uses of a number of words (s and f are used most frequently but not obnoxiously)Violence: talk about suicide (quite a bit, can be disturbing for some), instances of teenagers fighting and hurting each other
3.5 stars

It is worth it, stick with itThis is lovely story that introduces intriguing characters amidst many twists and turns. Yes, the protagonist can be hard to like, and yes, the many characters can seem cluttered. However, it is incredibly satisfying in the end. 4 stars because the beginning could do a better job of grabbing the reader.

Ehh it was ok

"webb once said that a narnie smile was a revelation and, at this moment, i need a revelation. and i get one."reread after years (thanks to haivan ❤️) and i loved the story even more this time around, which i didn't think was possible. though the last 20 pages or so were a blur because of my tears, these characters and their story will always have a special place in my heart 🥺
A little slow and confusing in the beginning but everything comes together.
Minus one star because I was confused. A LOT. And I want to slap all the adults in this book. HARD. But wowza what an fantastic emotional rollercoaster.

It was a good book. I think I would have enjoyed it more if it weren't for the book discussions we did about this book in school. Teared up a lil reading this one in your honor @Jess Chen

Once again, Melina Machetta captivated me attention with this novel. At the age of 7, Taylor was abandoned by her mom at a 7-Eleven in Jellicoe. When she was 14, Taylor attempted to run away to Sydney to find her mom. But the boy she was with called for help, and her journey was cut short. Three years later, Taylor is now the head of her House at Jellicoe school, and she must take lead in the annual territory wars between the school, the Townies and the Cadets. But when Hannah, the closest thing Taylor has to a parent, Taylor starts down a path of discovery that will reveals a tragic history on the Jellicoe Road. One that she is a part of. I truly enjoyed reading this book. I enjoyed the territory wars between the three factions and how this year's leaders have entangled histories with each other. As this novel is told from Taylor's POV, it is interesting to see her view of things contrasted against the dialogue of other characters. There is a particular instance where we learn that despite Taylor's behavior, the girls in her house truly care about her. There book contains lessons on friendship, the pain and healing found in tragedy, and how a single life event can completely alter the course of ones life. The story has a few triggers. It mildly touches on drugs and the destruction they bring about, and there is one mention of child pedophilia. However, suicide plays a heavier hand in the book.Looking back on the book, I realize there are plenty of characters involved in the story that I wish we got to know a bit better. In the moment, I was caught up in Taylor's experiences, but I would have loved to know more about Jonah, Chaz and Rafaela's histories. Also, I got stuck for a moment between the epilogue and chapter 1. The book states there is a 22 year time gap, but when chapter 1 starts, Taylor is 17 years old. Took me a few minutes longer than it should have to think "Oh, Taylor must not be one of the people involved in the epilogue."Overall, a great read. This is the second work of Melina Marchetta I've read. I enjoy her writing style and stories, so I'll definitely be checking out her other works!

On the Jellicoe Road covers so much territory, so many issues and quite a lot of characters, but it is not overdone. I loved this book. It made me nostalgic of my childhood and reminded me of the 'gangs' we would form in my tiny primary school of just 40 kids, where each gang had a peppercorn tree as their base and there would be battles for territory and people. One gang even made a tunnel. So I found the main storyline and premise of the territory wars between the Jellicoe School, the cadets and the townies absolutely believable. Melina Marchetta can write such amazing and complex characters, and Taylor Markham is the perfect example. At times Taylor is all about Taylor, but she is also vulnerable and can bring people together. I don't even know what to write to do this book justice, there are so many good things in the mix. I was sad to finish the book and leave the characters behind (there were real tears), but I hope to return to them another time in the future. The audiobook reading by Rebecca Macauley was fabulous and I will seek out more of the books she has narrated.

3.5 – This was a book I wish I had the patience to read as an attentively challenged younger teenager. I couldn’t really appreciate much of what went on in the earlier chapters as a twenty-year-old but it’s the kind of storytelling that would have compelled me to write more nuance to my material at that age instead of going stagnant in my later teens.Marchetta offered little distinctions to set out a clearer picture of the grounds or the characters but I take it down as personal style and it’s not like it worked against her. The focus she set upon literary devices such as a Chekhov’s Gun was pronounced enough for younger readers to appreciate without making it unnecessarily complex. The text was haunting and wistful. It’s not the kind that would have made it difficult for me to put down but if I do, I’d somehow regret it because the story is littered with bits and pieces that are easily relevant to the plot later. I did get a little annoyed at some points when something is mentioned or introduced and the reader was expected to just take that in as it is despite how slightly important it is to remember it later in the story. It was a good piece. Yet I personally didn’t appreciate how the intentionally dispersed excerpts muddled the story in a way that hindered it rather than stylise or emphasise the plot.

This book is exactly the reason I cannot, to this day, figure out when to give up on a book and when to keep going. The beginning didn’t make sense to me. It felt like there were too many characters and too many stories being thrown at me all at once and I didn’t understand how they fit together. I was annoyed every time I picked it up, and wanted to put it down just as often. I was 180 pages in and at that point I felt if I stopped I would have wasted all that time I’d already spent on it. And it had such good reviews I had to wonder what I was missing. I wanted to know why people thought it was so good. So I kept going and it paid off. I had ALL the feelings when it was over. Such a lovely and heartbreaking story of love, loss, family and friendship. I’m so glad I did stick with it!

Bored me to death. Reviews said that it will get interesting and pieces would fit halfway or by 2/3 of the book but I just couldn’t wait. Can’t connect with the characters and story’s kind of confusing.
Re-reading a book you love feels like going home after a long time away. Melina Marchetta, you give me so many feelings.
why don’t i get to start territory wars with students from other schools
I thought I wouldn't enjoy re-reading this. I was wrong.

This has pretty much been on my reading list since it first came out in 2008. The original cover always intrigued me, and I'd see it everywhere at the library, book stores, and in my digital suggestions and recommendations. But then whenever I read the synopsis, I was always like, "Ehhhhh...."I have now finally read it!!!It was good. It was hard for me to get into at first. I had numerous false starts. But once I got going, I was fairly sucked in. I'm glad to have finally read it, but it won't be a book I'm revisiting any time soon.

I went through a lot of different feelings while reading this book; beginning with confusion. Once I thought I had a grip on what was going on I didn't really care but then I become consumed with needing to know what had happened in the past in.Too much teenage romance and angst for me but for lovers of YA I can imagine this being a real treat. It's beautifully written and draws you in.

this book was exceptional. fascinating, gripping, well-written, heartbreaking, beautiful- the english language needs more words to describe this one. i loved the characters, the plot, the way everything was revealed to us. be ready not to leave your bed for 7 hours once you open this book. i couldn’t recommend it highly enough.everyone has that one book or tv show or movie they wish they could erase from their memory and soak in again - this one is mine.
Amazing all the emotions

Super late to the game on this one, but it has got to be my new favorite book. I was confused at times until I got further along in the story but it was SO well written. I can already tell I’ll be reading it again and again that’s how much I love it. Also, Jonah Griggs has stolen my heart. Love his character. And Taylor Markham is one great character as well.

This is one of my favorite YA novels. I can't recommend it enough. I've read it multiple times, and each time I start again, I'm immediately pulled into Taylor's world. I always find something new, whether a character or a brief excerpt of prose, to fall in love with. Marchetta has a way of weaving a complex narrative together and making you swoon for Jonah Griggs in a way that will have this story sticking with you long after you read the last page.

Emo! Melodrama! Reviews for this book are very mixed, from "oh-my-gawd-I-loved-it!" to "omg-I-hated-it!". I can't say I hated it but I didn't like it. For about half of the book -I am lying, for the WHOLE book- I was 🤔 with the whole war game thing. What was the purpose of that game?? I thought I was reading a dystopian book... it didn't make any sense.Taylor, the MC, was either crying or being angry.. the whole book. Her love interest was another emo. Was there any happiness for those people? Hannah's story was MEH... only around the end we know who is who, so because it didn't interest me, when I was reading, Webb had the same face as Fitz and Jude, and Narnie and Tate were the same girl, so I had zero attach to these characters.Nope, i didn't like this book. Made me think the whole time "what is the point of this story?"

this was honestly the saddest book i've ever read in my life but so damn beautiful at the same time that it did something to me and now I'm broken and I'll need therapy for the rest of my life because I'll never be able to get over it

Reading through chapter 12 (page 140 out of 400), I was so utterly bored that I decided to give up, literally mid-sentence. And I don’t quit books easily. However, at 35% percent into the story, the writer should have provided a general overview, but this novel was entirely directionless. Without the blurb, I would not have had a clue what is going on. This scene threw me off: a panel of senior students from a boarding school discussing territorial rights with the leaders of the local school kids and a neighbouring military school. In fact, the council is about access to waterways - as if any of them had any actual claim to the land. This territorial dispute is never even properly explained. The novel seems to have two main characters. On the one hand, there is Taylor, now 17 [I will never understand the trend to upgrade occupations into female first names], who at 11 was abandoned by her mother at a petrol station, and at 14 tried to run away from said boarding school to find her mother. On the run, she somehow fraternized with Jonah, a "Cadet" and now her antagonist. However, this backstory is structured as one big secret with only morsels of information thrown in. Taylor is also a particularly mopey, unappealing character. Yawn. Then there is Hannah, a woman in her 30s who survived a car crash as a child. She lives on the school premises and is Taylor’s friend. Somehow she is a main character, even though she has been missing since page 1. Again, lots of mysterious hints. Apparently, at the end you find out how all the events and characters are connected to each other. But I obviously don’t care to find out. I don’t know why this book is so successful. It’s just so dull. So, goodbye.

Read this for the first time in 2014 and thought it was probably my favourite book so I was worried to reread it and it be not as good as in my memory but it was better!!!! Amazing, I love Melina Marchetta's writing - she gets no hype!!

The first third/half of this book took so much work to get through. It was so confusing!! I was finally able to just go with it and there ended up being a lot that I liked about it, but I don’t know if I can really say I loved it.
I found it hard to read at the start and considered giving up but I’m glad I persevered because I ended up really enjoying it.
Easily one of my all-time favorite contemporary books. I wish I could reset time and read it for the first time all over again.
